name: Mount Chocorua

seo.meta_title: Piper Trail: Trail Conditions, Maps & Parking 2026
seo.meta_description: Explore Mount Chocorua (3,490 ft) in New Hampshire. 3 trails with maps, elevation profiles & current conditions.

schema_place.name: Mount Chocorua
schema_place.description: Mount Chocorua is a 3,490 foot peak in New Hampshire offering hiking trails with scenic views.

mainEntity.name: How long does it take to hike Mount Chocorua?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most routes on Mount Chocorua take 2-4 hours round trip. The most popular trail is 5.4 miles with Moderate difficulty. Start early, especially on weekends when parking fills quickly.

mainEntity.name: Is Mount Chocorua hard to hike?

acceptedAnswer.text: Mount Chocorua is rated Moderate. At 3,490 feet, the trail offers a rewarding hike suitable for most fitness levels. Proper footwear and preparation are essential.

mainEntity.name: Do I need a permit to hike Mount Chocorua?

acceptedAnswer.text: No hiking permit is required for Mount Chocorua. However, parking fees may apply at trailheads (typically $3-5/day for WMNF or state parks). A WMNF parking pass covers most White Mountain trailheads.

mainEntity.name: What is the best trail to hike Mount Chocorua?

acceptedAnswer.text: The most popular route is the Piper Trail, offering Trail to Mount Chocorua summit..

mainEntity.name: When is the best time to hike Mount Chocorua?

acceptedAnswer.text: The best hiking season for Mount Chocorua is April through November. Spring wildflowers and fall foliage are particularly scenic.

page_content.description:
Rising to 3,490 feet, Mount Chocorua offers one of New Hampshire's finest hiking experiences. Whether you're seeking panoramic views, a family-friendly outing, or a quick escape into nature, this peak delivers.

Popular Routes

The most popular route, **Piper Trail**, covers 5.4 miles and is rated Moderate. Trail to Mount Chocorua summit.

Peak Bagging

**Extend Your Adventure:** Mount Passaconaway lies just 5.4 miles away, making it an excellent addition for ambitious hikers looking to bag multiple summits.

spring.title: Spring Conditions
spring.tips: Trail closures for mud season (April-May). Check conditions before heading out.

summer.title: Summer Conditions
summer.tips: Start early to avoid afternoon storms and parking issues. Peak crowds on weekends.

fall.title: Fall Conditions
fall.tips: Peak foliage brings peak crowds. Weekday hikes recommended. Watch for ice above treeline in late October.

winter.title: Winter Conditions
winter.tips: Traction devices recommended. Start early for daylight.

current_hazards: Hypothermia risk - temperatures 20-40F colder at summit
Trail markers may be buried under snow
